metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof The MERS-CoV receptor DPP4 as a candidate binding target of the SARS-CoV-2 spike The MERS-CoV receptor DPP4 as a candidate binding target of the SARS-CoV-2 spike 2 3 4

abstract.text: The MERS-CoV receptor DPP4 as a candidate binding target of the SARS-CoV-2 spike, ISCIENCE (2020),

body_text.text: As an emerging disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 44 2 (SARS-CoV-2, previously named 2019-nCoV), COVID-19 has since become a 45 global concern with the very-high level of risk. The pathogen SARS-CoV-2 has been 46 shown to be a member of betacoronaviruses closely related to the SARS-CoV and the 47 strain RaTG13 of bat origin (Zhou et al., 2020) . 48

The coronaviruses are enveloped ranking among the dangerous zoonotically emerging (Table 1 ). It is known that 121 ACE2 has been proposed to be a receptor of SARS-CoV-2. Since DPP4 obtained the 122 highest integration score (Table 1) , and it is also associated with a betacoronavirus by 123 acting as the receptor of MERS-CoV, we focused on it next.

By employing protein docking strategy, we investigated the potential interaction 144 mode between SARS-CoV-2-S RBD and DPP4. The atomic interaction details of the 145 binding interface showed that almost all of the contacting residues of DPP4 with 146 SARS-CoV-2-S RBD were consistent with those for binding with MERS-CoV-S 147 RBD (Table S1 ) (Song et al., 2014) . These residues include: DPP4 residue K267 with 148 Figure 1B and Table S1 ). In addition, DPP4 residue L294 and I295 can contribute 151
Van der Waals' forces to the binding (Table S1) The analysis of key residues for DPP4-binding ability acquirement of 171

According to the above results ( Figure 1A substitutions existed at the sites equivalent to E484 and adjacent residues of 186 SARS-CoV-2, and there were no mutations at the rest three key residues ( Figure S1) . 187
In addition, since the pangolin has been suspected as a zoonotic host of SARS-CoV-2, 188
we compared the sequences of human and pangolin DPP4 ( Figure 3C ). The result 189

showed that they shared all key residues ready to bind to both SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV-S could bind to DPP4, sharing the identical key binding residues of 219 DPP4 at the interfaces (Figure 1) . The results also suggested that the insertion and 220 substitutions at E484 and adjacent residues be essential for the entirely different 221 ability in binding to DPP4 between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV spikes, for adjacent 222 residues may also contribute to the structure change. It seems that the binding of 223 SARS-CoV-2-S and DPP4 is unique. Whereas, these kinds of mutations can naturally 224 occur as in the bat strain RaTG13 (Figure S1 ), though the residues may be different. 225

The only animal-origin betacoronavirus that possesses this potential binding ability 226 currently is one isolated from pangolins, containing these identical key residues in the 227 spike RBD sequences (Lam et al., 2020) . In addition, the models evaluated the 228 binding potential, interface residues and structures that were consistent with those 229 Comparison of the key residues between human and pangolin DPP4 protein 471

FIGREF0.text: great number of cases and deaths, but our understanding about the pathogen 23 SARS-CoV-2 remains largely unclear. The attachment of the virus with the 24 cell-surface receptor and a co-factor is the first step for the infection. Here, 25 bioinformatics approaches combining human-virus protein interaction prediction and 26 protein docking based on crystal structures have revealed the high affinity between 27 human dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) and the spike (S) receptor-binding domain of 28 SARS-CoV-2. Intriguingly, the crucial binding residues of DPP4 are identical to those 29 as bound to the MERS-CoV-S. Moreover, E484 insertion and adjacent substitutions 30 should be most essential for this DPP4-binding ability acquirement of 31 SARS-CoV-2-S compared with SARS-CoV-S. This potential utilization of DPP4 as a 32 binding target for SARS-CoV-2 may offer novel insight into the viral pathogenesis, 33 and help the surveillance and therapeutics strategy for meeting the challenge of 34 COVID-19. 35 36 INTRODUCTION 37 The ongoing outbreak of novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) that early reported at 38 Wuhan city of China in December of 2019 has rapidly been characterized as a 39 pandemic, transmitting to almost of all the countries or territories in the world. As of 40 27 March 2020, confirmed cases have exceeded 500,000 including 23,335 deaths 41 globally 42

FIGREF1.text: 49 pathogens (Song et al., 2019). There were another two severe betacoronavirus disease 50 outbreaks in humans since this century. They were SARS in 2003 and middle east 51 respiratory syndrome (MERS) started from 2012 (Song et al., 2019). Both 52 SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV were zoonotic agents transmitted from bats to 53 intermediate hosts such as palm civets or dromedary camels, and finally to humans 54 (Cui et al., 2019; Song et al., 2019). The coronavirus is a type of positive stranded 55 RNA virus with the spike (S) glycoprotein on the virion envelope mediating receptor 56 recognition through the receptor-binding domain (RBD), and membrane fusion 57 following the proteolytic cleavage into S1 and S2 subunits (Cui et al., 2019). The 58 receptors are predominant determinants for the host tropism and pathogenicity of the 59 viruses (Cui et al., 2019). Coronaviruses have evolved sophisticated receptor 60 recognition patterns. Spikes from related coronaviruses can recognize distinct 61 receptors, whereas spikes of distant coronaviruses can employ the same entry receptor. 62 For instance, SARS-CoV uses angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) as its main 63 receptor, and MERS-CoV engages the transmembrane dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4, 64 also known as CD26) as the primary receptor (Cui et al., 2019; Song et al., 2019; 65 Wang et al., 2013). A few reports have proposed that SARS-CoV-2 uses the 66 SARS-CoV receptor ACE2 for its cellular entry (Hoffmann et al., 2020; Letko et al., 67 2020; Zhou et al., 2020), though four out of five key residues within the RBD of 68 SARS-CoV-2 are mutated when compared with that of SARS-CoV (Zhou et al., 69 2020). ACE2 is also shared as a receptor of another human coronavirus, NL63, which 70 belongs to alphacoronavirus genara (Chan et al., 2016; Cui et al., 2019; Song et al., 71 2019). Additionally, the natural hosts of SARS-CoV-2 have been suggested to be bats 72 and pangolins resulting from analyses of the viral genome characteristics (Lam et al., 73 2020; Zhang et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2020), but an intermediate animal that directly 74 transmits SARS-CoV-2 to human has not been confirmed. 75 Intriguingly, the viral cell entry always requires multiple transmembrane proteins in 76 the target cell apart from the primary receptor (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Cui 77 et al., 2019). The coronavirus spikes are able to recognize a broad range of 78 cell-surface molecules in addition to the designated receptors for entry. These 79 molecules are called as coreceptors or attachment factors, which have been reported 80 to play critical roles in the viral propagation (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Cui 81 et al., 2019). The cellular susceptibility to virus infection may correlate with these 82 proteins' interactions, which help ensure the triggering of viral entry at an appropriate 83 place (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Cui et al., 2019). A receptor for one kind of 84 coronavirus can be utilized for a co-factor of the infection of another or even a distant 85 coronavirus. For example, the human coronavirus OC43 (hCoV-OC43) receptor, 86 O-acetylated sialic acid, has been suggested as an attachment factor in the binding of 87 hCoV-HKU1 to the cell surface (Chu et al., 2018; Cui et al., 2019). The 88 carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell adhesion molecule 5 (CEACAM5) and 89 glucose-regulated protein GRP78 are identified as attachment factors that could 90 enhance the attachment in nonpermissive cells and entry in susceptible cells for 91 MERS-CoV (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018). GRP78 can simultaneously help the 92 cell entry of the bat coronavirus HKU9 except for MERS-CoV (Chu et al., 2018). 93 Like CEACAM5, CEACAM1 is a member of the same family, which serves as the 94 receptor of the animal coronavirus, mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) (Chan et al., 2016; 95 Chu et al., 2018; Cui et al., 2019). Moreover, the tetraspanin CD9 was identified as a 96 host cell-surface factor that augments MERS-CoV entry by scaffolding the receptor 97 DPP4 and the protease TMPRSS2 (Earnest et al., 2017). The latter can act as a 98 priming factor in the early infection of SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, or SARS-CoV-2 99 (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Hoffmann et al., 2020). In the case of SARS-CoV, 100 dendritic cell-specific inter-cellular adhesion molecule-3-grabbing nonintegrin 101 (DCSIGN) and DCSIGN-related facilitate virus entry by interacting with S protein 102 (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Cui et al., 2019). It remains unclear whether 103 coronaviruses bind to these attachment factors through RBDs of the viral spikes. 104 Little attention is given to the cell-surface co-factors in facilitating the attachment and 105 entry of SARS-CoV-2 currently. Whereas, study on this aspect may help understand 106 the viral pathogenesis, which remains largely unknown. 107 108 RESULTS 109 The prediction of interaction between human proteins and the 110 SARS-CoV-2 spike 111 The interaction of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of SARS-CoV-2 spike (S) 112 protein and ACE2, as well as the monomer proteins of DPP4, ACE2, and coronavirus 113 spike proteins, have been resolved by crystallography (Lan et al., 2020; Walls et al., 114 2020). An integrative human-virus protein interaction inference based on protein 115 crystal structures was used to predict human proteins probably interacted with 116 SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. In the prediction, interolog mapping (IM), 117 domain-domain interaction (DDI), and machine learning (ML) were combined to 118 evaluate the score for each protein-protein interaction (Schleker et al., 2012; von 119 Mering et al., 2005; Yang et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2014). The result showed that both 120 ACE2 and DPP4 ranked in the top five human proteins

FIGREF2.text: The affinity of three betacoronavirus spikes and DPP4 or ACE2 126By using a set of methods combining mechanics energies with the generalized Born127 and surface area continuum solvation (MM-GBSA) and molecular dynamics (MD) 128 simulation (Genheden and Ryde, 2015; Maier et al., 2015; Miller et al., 2012; 129 Miyamoto and Kollman, 1992; Salomon-Ferrer et al., 2013; Toukmaji et al., 2000), 130 the binding free energy for the RBD of coronavirus spike (CoV-S) proteins to DPP4 131 or ACE2 were calculated (Figure 1A). According to the free energy values (far less 132 than zero), the bindings of SARS-CoV-S/ACE2 and MERS-CoV/DPP4 are consistent 133 to what has been reported. There were no potential interactions of 134 SARS-CoV-S/DPP4 and MERS-CoV/ACE2 (free energy values >0 kcal/mol). 135 Among the three coronaviruses, only SARS-CoV-2-S could theoretically bind to both 136 ACE2 and DPP4. In terms of the binding of DPP4 with SARS-CoV-2-S, the affinity 137 (-34.8 kcal/mol) was lower than that of DPP4 with MERS-CoV-S (-38.3 kcal/mol), 138 ACE2 with SARS-CoV-2-S (-39.2 kcal/mol), as well as ACE2 with SARS-CoV-S 139 (-47.8 kcal/mol) (Figure 1A). 140 141

FIGREF3.text: , not forming hydrogen bonds as in 152 the binding to MERS-CoV-S(Song et al., 2014). Though the homology between 153 SARS-CoV-2-S and MERS-CoV-S RBDs is low (19.1%), they shared identical 154 binding residues of DPP4 at the interfaces (Figure 1C). According to the known 155 structural information of DPP4 interacting with MERS-CoV-S RBD, the residue pairs 156 (DPP4 residue K267, R336, R317, Q344 with MERS-CoV-S RBD D539, Y499, 157 D510, E513, respectively) contributed significantly to the interaction(Table S1) 158(Song et al., 2014). All of the four DPP4 residues were also observed to be involved 159 in the binding interface of DPP4/SARS-CoV-2 RBD, contributing to free energy by 160 forming hydrogen bonds. Thus, these four DPP4 residues were regarded as the crucial161 residues of DPP4 interacting with SARS-CoV-2-S RBD. When compared every two 162 of the three CoV-S RBD structures, SARS-CoV-2-S RBD and SARS-CoV-S RBD 163 also showed the lowest root mean square deviation (RMSD) value (1.34Å), which is 164 in line with their high identity (Figure 2). While SARS-CoV-2-S RBD is more 165 structurally similar to MERS-CoV RBD than SARS-CoV RBD to MERS-CoV RBD, 166 with 2.95 Å and 3.44 Å of RMSD values respectively (Figure 2). This may help 167 explain why SARS-CoV-2-S RBD can bind to the MERS-CoV receptor of DPP4, but 168 SARS-CoV-S RBD cannot. 169 7 170

FIGREF4.text: , SARS-CoV-S does not bind 173 with DPP4. We compared the sequences at the key residues of SARS-CoV-2-S RBD 174 equivalent to that of SARS-CoV-S RBD. Two out of four substitutions or insertion 175 happened in SARS-CoV-2-S RBD (Figure 3A). In particular, at E484 (potentially 176 binding with DPP4 R317) and adjacent residues, there were an insertion and several 177substitutions. The substitution of Q498Y also made the potential binding between 178 SARS-CoV-2-S RBD with DPP4 K267. Furthermore, the virtual mutation of a single 179 of these residues in SARS-CoV-2-S RBD resulted in considerable reduction of 180 affinity, especially for the substitutions of D405A and E484A (Figure 3B). Actually, 181there is no mutation at D405 and Y489/N487 compared to the equivalent residues of 182 SARS-CoV-S RBD (Figure 3A). Thus, E484 should be the most important residue for 183 the binding ability. We also checked the amino acids in the spike RBD of the bat 184 strain RaTG13(Zhou et al., 2020), an insertion of T (not E) and a few different 185

FIGREF5.text: 190MERS-CoV spikes(Song et al., 2014). These key residues presented in humanDPP4  191    are also conserved in other animal species, including macaque, pig, camel, horse, 192 sheep, bovine, rabbit and bat(Song et al., 2014).193 194 DISCUSSION 195 Coronaviruses commonly recognize a wide range of cell-surface targets in addition to 196 the receptors (Chan et al., 2016; Chu et al., 2018; Cui et al., 2019). For MERS-CoV, 197 when the receptor DPP4 and the protease TMPRSS2 are sparse on the cell surface, 198 CD9 can play an important role in rendering the early, efficient entry (Earnest et al., 199 2017). Before the fusion occurs, sufficient proteolytic cleavage is likely to form an 200 activated cluster in regions of the cell membrane with a relatively high local 201 concentration of these entry factors (Cui et al., 2019; Earnest et al., 2017). This sort of 202 characteristics may give the coronaviruses a physiological advantage in establishing 203 efficient infections in animal or human hosts, thus contributing to the high 204 pathogenicity of them. With the ongoing of the pandemic of COVID-19, the causes 205 for a lot of clinical features remain largely to be investigated. Experiments in an 206 animal model have showed that the severity of COVID-19 seems intermediate 207 between SARS and MERS (Rockx et al., 2020). And, the receptor ACE2 is 208 suboptimal for the infection of SARS-CoV-2 in binding to the spike (Procko, 2020). 209 The immunological characterization study showed the infection of SARS-CoV-2 in 210 immune cells, and especially, which is not correlated with the expression of ACE2 211 (Wei et al., 2020). Therefore, it seems that ACE2 should have employed some helpers 212 in the swift infection and pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2. 213 214 In this study, according to the binding free energy, the affinity of 215 ACE2/SARS-CoV-2-S is stronger than that of DPP4/SARS-CoV-2-S (Figure 1A), 216 suggesting the priority of the binding of ACE2 to SARS-CoV-2-S and the leading role 217 of ACE2 as a receptor. The results demonstrated that both SARS-CoV-2-S and 218

FIGREF6.text: known virus-host interactions, including SARS-CoV-S/ACE2, MERS-CoV-S/DPP4, 230 verifying the feasibility of our methodology. 231 232 DPP4 is the MERS-CoV receptor, thus possessing advantages in mediating the 233 infection of a coronavirus. It was shown that DPP4 was not able to mediate the 234 SARS-CoV-2 entry independently in nonpermissive cells such as Hela and BHK2 235 (Hoffmann et al., 2020; Letko et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2020). However, it remains 236 unknown for its role on the attachment and/or entry during SARS-CoV-2 infection 237 into permissive cells. In the present approach, we have revealed that DPP4 can act as 238 a candidate binding target of the SARS-CoV-2-S RBD. DPP4 is a serine protease that 239 is abundantly distributed in human tissues, playing roles as a multi-functional protein 240 (Aliyari Serej et al., 2017). Apart from lower respiratory tract, kidney, liver, small 241 intestine and prostate, DPP4 presents in placenta, fibroblasts of lung and wounded 242 skin, muscle, as well as central nervous systems (Aliyari Serej et al., 2017; Cheng et 243 al., 2019; Cui et al., 2019; Song et al., 2019). Moreover, DPP4 is widely expressed on 244 activated immune cells including CD4(+) and CD8(+) T cells, B cells, NK cells, 245 dendritic cells, and macrophages (Shao et al., 2020; Song et al., 2019). It is capable of 246 modulating the production of cytokines, chemokines and peptide hormones, thus 247 being involved in various immune or inflammatory diseases (Shao et al., 2020). But 248 for all, we will have to know the interaction between DPP4 and the primary receptor 249 ACE2, and how DPP4 may help the entry of SARS-CoV-2 into host cells. 250 251 The serine protease inhibitor, camostat mesylate, has been confirmed to efficiently 252 suppress the infection of SARS-CoV-2 for the purpose of TMPRSS2 inhibition 253 (Hoffmann et al., 2020). As DPP4 is also a serine protease, this would be reasonably 254 suitable for the inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 infection even if DPP4 is a cell-surface 255 target of the viral spike. Inhibitors against DPP4 could be developed for the 256 COVID-19 therapeutics. The conservative property of DPP4 among mammals might 257 allow the SARS-CoV-2 to maintain in animal reservoirs and to confer recombination 258 events. Thus, it would be necessary to consider as wide as animals in the surveillance 259 of SARS-CoV-2. 260 261 In conclusion, bioinformatics approaches based on the protein crystal structures have 262 predicted that the MERS-CoV receptor DDP4 might act as a candidate binding target 263 or coreceptor of SARS-CoV-2. Intriguingly, the crucial binding residues in DPP4 are 264 identical with those for DPP4 as bound to MERS-CoV-S RBD. The mutations at 265 E484 and adjacent residues might be mostly important to contribute to the 266 acquirement of this binding ability. This model provides new insight into the 267 interaction between SARS-CoV-2 and the host. In-depth study around this aspect may 268 provide better understanding on the host tropism and pathogenicity of SARS-CoV-2, 269 and help the surveillance and therapeutics strategy for meeting the challenge of the 270 viral infection. 271 272LIMITATIONS OF THE STUDY 273By employing bioinformatics approaches based on protein crystal structures, our 274 study revealed that SARS-CoV-2 may utilize DPP4, the MERS-CoV receptor, as its 275 binding target. The methodology resolved all the protein complexes between virus 276 spikes and human receptors with fundamentally consistent interfaces to those reported, 277 demonstrating the feasibility of using the methods. However, the limitation of the 278 methodology is that it is not able to predict how two human proteins compete the 279 binding site in structural space, since both ACE2 and DPP4 can bind at the same RBD 280 of SARS-CoV-2. According to the result of free energy calculation, the affinity of 281 ACE2/SARS-CoV-2-S is stronger than that of DPP4/SARS-CoV-2-S, this may result 282 the priority of the binding of ACE2 to SARS-CoV-2-S. Whereas, the expression 283 amount of these two human proteins may be different in different cell types or 284 patients, and result in an unknown binding mode.

Note that all the complexes were downloaded or predicted through 450 ZDOCK based on protein crystal structures. (B) The structure of predicted interaction 451 complex of SARS-CoV-2-S RBD (yellow) and DPP4 (wheat). The detailed binding 452 interface is magnified separately as indicated. (C) The structural model of 453 SARS-CoV-2-S RBD bound with DPP4 is superimposed with the crystal structure of 454 MERS-CoV-S RBD. The contact residues of DPP4 (wheat) bound with either 455 MERS-CoV-S RBD (light blue) or SARS-CoV-2-S RBD (yellow) are displayed in 456 the right two panels. 457 Comparison of the RBD structures of every two among three viruses. 459 RMSD (root mean square deviation) value (Å) can be used for the estimation of the 460 structural similarity of every two proteins. The smaller of RMSD is, the higher 461 similarity between both structures is. 462 Comparison and mutation of the key residues for the binding of 464 SARS-CoV-2-S RBD and DPP4. 465 (A) Sequence comparison of the key residues between SARS-CoV-2-S and 466 SARS-CoV-S RBDs. There are an insertion and adjacent substitutions at E484, and a 467 Q498Y substitution in SARS-CoV-2-S RBD. (B) Effect of mutation at the key 468 residues on the binding free energy. Virtual mutations of single key residues could 469 impact the free energy, especially for D405A and E484A. WT, wild type. (C) 470
